Improving UX in an iOS App

2020, Jul 02    

Introduction

While other companies design beutiful hardware, excel at marketing, hire good lawyers, and manufacture gadgets at scale, no other company makes software as intuitive, carefully crafted, or just plain fun. If there is unique magic in Apple’s products, it’s in the software. –Creative Selection by Ken Kocienda

This blog post was written concurently along with my work on The Rowing App. Some things here apply to this app specificly, but the general ideas apply to all apps. It isn’t meant to be an exhastive list of ways to improve UX, but adoption of some ideas can help improve a user’s experience in any app.

It’s all in the details.

What makes a great user experience? Convienience, satisfaction, accessiblity, App app that is satisfying feels good to use.

Improving Accessibilty

Dealing with complex inputs in an app is a hard thing to get right. You have to take a step back and think about how the user would want your app to handle it. The ability to have empathy and see your app from the user’s perspective as an iOS developer is key to being able to improve UX.

..

Providing the user with a prediciton of what they would want

keyboard selector for splits accessory buttosn for predicting text input textfield editing in a tableiview

Improving the Feel

A great iOS app isn’t just easy to use, but it feels good to use too. This is the difference between iOS and Android. A user wants to feel rewarded after preforming an action. That reward can come in many different forms, like a smooth animation or haptic feedback just to name a few.

Haptics

UISegmentedControls are a great place to start for adding haptic feedback to an app. Try touching a segmented control with and without haptic feedback added to it. The result will make you never want to add one to your app without haptics ever again. And, thanks to Swift, this is an incredibly easy improvement to make.

Even though iOS users can turn off haptics in all apps, giving them the option to turn off haptics in your app specifically is also a great idea. UserDefaults is a great place to store a user preference like this and the value can be checked when initializing the feedback generator.
